docs.lead_paragraph: AIDS has long been considered primarily a men's disease. But yesterday the United Nations reported for the first time that more women than men were infected with the AIDS virus in Africa, the site of a vast majority of such infections in the world. In a report released in advance of World AIDS Day on Dec. 1, the United Nations said that of the 22.3 million adults in sub-Sahara Africa with H.I.V., the AIDS virus, 12.2 million, or 55 percent, are women.

headline.main: More African Women Have AIDS Than Men

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If the French are in fact healthier than Americans despite a fattier diet, there are better explanations for why this might be so than the notion that if you don't worry that your food might give you a coronary, it won't (''French Diet Secret: If It Feels Good, Eat It,'' Week in Review, Nov. 21). The French live more humanely than Americans, and their attitude toward food is only a small part of that.

headline.main: For the French, Food Isn't Everything

docs.lead_paragraph: Proposed federal rules aimed at preventing on-the-job injuries from repetitive motion touched off a debate today over how such injuries occur, what they cost American businesses and what can be done to avoid them. Just as federal bans on sexual harassment in the workplace led to years of training programs, lawsuits and arguments over compensatory payments, the rules proposed today by Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman will generate thousands of claims and counterclaims, labor and business groups said.

headline.main: Business and Labor Differ On Ergonomic Proposals

docs.lead_paragraph: Just as the states are about to take in a torrent of money from their settlement with tobacco companies, New York's lawmakers are moving toward a consensus that most if not all of the state's share should be spent on health. Earlier this year, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed spending three-quarters of the money on reducing the state's debts; the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said a large chunk of it might go toward school construction; and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, said he wanted a major share to go to tax cuts.

headline.main: Albany Is Near Deal on Using Tobacco Share

docs.lead_paragraph: Once cadavers and evidence are removed from a typical crime scene, the police and paramedics drive away, leaving a traumatized family and an opportunity for a delicate enterprise now quietly evident across the land. ''The family just went through this horrific event and now they have to clean up, too?'' Becky Della-Rodolfa said, describing the rationale of her private Philadelphia business that specializes in the cleaning and repairing of the aftermath of homicides, suicides and other mayhem.

headline.main: The Corpse Is Gone; Enter Quietly the Cleaners

docs.lead_paragraph: As her meditation session drew to a close, Mary Bryant found it difficult to get up from her chair. Not only was it hard to break the calming spell cast by her instructor, but Ms. Bryant was still stiff from running the New York City Marathon and pushing, for the whole 26 miles, a flower-strewed wheelchair dedicated to a late friend and fellow breast cancer patient. Finally, the tall, slender Ms. Bryant summoned her resolve and managed to stand while repeating her teacher's suggested thought, ''I am here now.'' She added her own twist, ''I am here now, and I am cancer free.''

headline.main: A Therapy Gains Ground In Hospitals: Meditation

docs.lead_paragraph: His jaw is no longer wired shut and his shattered fingers are beginning to move again, but Kent Gasser's face still bears the signs of a merciless beating he survived six weeks ago in Riverside Park, when a stranger bashed his head with a rock in the middle of the day. Despite lingering double vision, a damaged right hand and a crooked nose, Mr. Gasser said he is almost ready to return to his acting career -- and his job as a waiter.

headline.main: Victim of an Earlier Random Assault Is Recovering
